questions.text: A 36-year-old man comes to the emergency department 4 hours after a bike accident for severe pain and swelling in his right leg. He has not had a headache, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, or blood in his urine. He has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease and allergic rhinitis. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 17 years and drinks an average of one alcoholic beverage daily. His medications include levocetirizine and pantoprazole. He is in moderate distress. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 112/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple bruises over both lower extremities and the face. There is swelling surrounding a 2 cm laceration 13 cm below the right knee. The lower two-thirds of the tibia is tender to palpation and the skin is pale and cool to the touch. The anterior tibial, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis pulses are weak. Capillary refill time of the right big toe is 4 seconds. Passive dorsiflexion of his right foot causes severe pain in his calf. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. An x-ray of the right leg shows a dislocated fracture of the tibial center with posterior displacement of the distal tibial part. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

One of the many indications of LMWH is the treatment of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). DVT can manifest with swelling of the lower limb and pain in the calf muscle on dorsiflexion of the foot. However, in patients with DVT, the extremities are usually warm and have a reddish-purple hue, normal pulses, and/or distended superficial veins.

B) INCORRECT:

Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) with an intramedullary nail are usually the treatment of choice for many types of open fractures of the tibial shaft, which this patient has. However, the presence of compartment syndrome warrants a more urgent procedure to save the limb before any definitive therapy is implemented.

C) INCORRECT:

An above knee cast may be used to nonsurgically treat a noncomminuted, minimally displaced tibial shaft fracture. However, this patient's fracture is open and has significant displacement, which requires surgical treatment. Regardless, a cast is contraindicated in this patient with compartment syndrome as it would drastically increase compartment pressure and further increase the risk of developing limb ischemia.

D) CORRECT:

Fasciotomy is the treatment of choice for compartment syndrome. It should be conducted within six hours of the onset of clinical symptoms (to prevent necrosis, irreversible nerve damage, and possible amputation) and followed up with open wound management. The diagnosis is primarily clinical; however, needle manometry to calculate the delta pressure (diastolic blood pressure - intracompartmental pressure) is often performed to confirm the diagnosis. A delta pressure < 30 mm Hg confirms acute compartment syndrome, which is an indication for fasciotomy. For patients who present extremely late (3–5 days after onset), amputation is the treatment of last resort.

E) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin is used to treat skin and soft tissue infections caused by anaerobic bacteria and certain gram-positive organisms such as MRSA. However, the history of trauma in this patient along with pale, cool skin instead of warm, erythematous skin, and the absence of fever suggest a noninfectious condition. If surgery is indicated, clindamycin is considered an alternative to cefazolin for surgical prophylaxis in patients with a beta-lactam allergy. However, the presence of compartment syndrome in this patient warrants a more urgent procedure to save the limb before any definitive therapy can be implemented.

F) INCORRECT:

Placing a filter within the inferior vena cava is indicated to treat and/or prevent pulmonary embolism in patients with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) when anticoagulant therapy is either contraindicated or ineffective. DVT can manifest with swelling of the lower limb, and pain in the calf muscle on dorsiflexion of the foot, as seen in this patient. But the extremities in a patient with DVT are usually warm with a reddish purple hue, normal pulses, and/or distended superficial veins.
questions.hint: Findings of a tibial fracture, pale, cool skin, weak peripheral pulses, increased capillary refill time, and pain in the calf muscle on passively dorsiflexing the foot are consistent with acute compartment syndrome and impending limb ischemia.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man presents with right knee pain and swelling after a fall at a rock climbing gym the previous day. He fell approximately 3 meters, landed on his feet, and experienced immediate pain in his right leg. He is unable to bear weight and is using crutches.
His right knee is swollen, there is a large joint effusion, and there is ecchymosis over the anterior knee. There is no associated erythema, skin breakdown, or obvious bony deformity. The knee area is tender to palpation, with increased pain over the lateral joint line and proximal tibia. Flexion is limited to 30 degrees. Ligamentous testing is limited because of patient discomfort, but there appears to be some asymmetric laxity with valgus stress testing. The lower extremity is neurovascularly intact.
Radiographs are obtained (figures 1 and 2).
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A meniscal tear would be accompanied by mechanical symptoms, such as catching or locking, in addition to a joint effusion and a positive McMurray sign. Patients with meniscal tears are typically able to bear weight but have pain at end flexion or extension.

B) CORRECT:

The tibial plateau is the critical weight-bearing portion of the lower extremity and therefore affects the motion and stability of the knee joint. Tibial plateau fractures in otherwise healthy, young individuals result from high-energy trauma, such as a motor vehicle crash, a fall from a considerable height, or a sports injury. Early recognition of injury to the plateau is important for maintaining long-term function of the knee. Imaging is required to make the diagnosis.

This patient's radiographs demonstrate a large effusion with hemarthrosis. The anteroposterior radiograph demonstrates cortical disruption through the lateral tibial plateau with associated compression of the plateau and a fibular head fracture. The tibial spine and medial plateau are intact.

Fractures of the tibial plateau are often intra-articular and involve the cancellous bone of the proximal tibia. The honeycomb design of cancellous bone bleeds easily when injured and is recognized as hemarthrosis on a radiograph. Lateral tibial plateau fractures are commonly associated with fibular head fractures, but the fibular fracture is not as clinically significant because the fibula does not provide considerable stability to the joint or affect the ability to bear weight.

Key learning point: High-energy trauma to the knee resulting in effusion, inability to bear weight, and radiographic evidence of hemarthrosis is most consistent with a diagnosis of tibial plateau fracture.

C) INCORRECT:

The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) inserts onto the anterior tibial spine, located in the intercondylar eminence. With high-energy injuries, an avulsion fracture of the anterior tibial plateau can occur, typically associated with rupture of the ACL. Although physical examination in this type of injury often shows hemarthrosis, the tibial spine would not appear intact on the radiograph, as it does in this case. Further physical examination in patients who can tolerate it would include abnormal findings on maneuvers that assess ACL integrity, such as the Lachman and anterior drawer tests.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute compartment syndrome is a serious complication of tibial plateau injuries in which the swelling related to the fracture causes compression of neurovascular structures of the leg, such as the common peroneal nerve and popliteal vessels, and can lead to necrosis of tissue. Thus, the neurovascular component of the physical examination is of extreme importance, and if compartment syndrome is suspected, orthopedic consultation for possible surgical intervention is imperative. In this case, the lower extremity is neurovascularly intact.

E) INCORRECT:

Proximal tibial fractures do not extend to the articular surface of the joint and do not involve the cancellous bone of the plateau. Hemarthrosis is not an expected finding with such fractures.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the clinic after an unwitnessed fall at home. He began limping immediately after catching his foot on a rug. He cries when his lower leg is touched, especially along the inner side of the tibia, but has minimal bruising or swelling. He refuses to bear weight on the affected leg and prefers to be carried. Plain radiographs appear unremarkable at first glance.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteomyelitis presents with systemic infection signs like fever and malaise, and a gradual onset of localized pain. The immediate post-trauma pain and absence of systemic symptoms suggest a mechanical injury rather than an infectious process.

B) INCORRECT:

Nonaccidental trauma is considered when injury mechanisms are unclear or multiple injuries are present. Here, a clear history of a fall and isolated tibial tenderness without additional suspicious findings reduces the likelihood of inflicted injury.

C) INCORRECT:

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis typically involves chronic joint swelling and morning stiffness, not acute post-trauma pain. The immediate limp and localized tibial pain after a fall do not align with the chronic inflammatory process of juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

D) CORRECT:

Toddler fracture is a minimally displaced spiral fracture of the tibia, common in young children after low-energy twisting injuries. It manifests with localized tenderness, especially along the medial tibia, and an immediate refusal to bear weight. Despite minimal swelling or bruising, clinical suspicion is crucial as initial radiographs may appear normal. The fracture's subtle nature and the rapid remodeling ability of pediatric bones necessitate careful evaluation. Conservative treatment with immobilization is typically effective, promoting optimal healing.

Key learning point: In toddlers, a twisting injury to the leg often results in a 'toddler fracture,' which is a subtle spiral fracture of the tibia that can cause refusal to walk.
Image Description:

X-ray lower leg (AP view) of a child

A nondisplaced spiral fracture of the distal tibial diaphysis (arrows) is not accompanied by conspicuous periosteal reaction. The fibula is normal.

Toddler fractures are usually accidental injuries. They can be subtle and sometimes require additional views, follow-up radiographs, or bone scintigraphy for diagnosis. Ultrasound may also be useful.

questions.text: A 28-year-old motorcyclist presents after a collision with severe pain and swelling in the right lower leg. Examination reveals tenderness along the tibial shaft and an obvious deformity. The patient is unable to dorsiflex the right foot or feel light touch over the dorsal foot between the first and second toes. Dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are palpable. X-rays show a displaced tibial shaft fracture. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Apply posterior long-leg splint and orthopedic consultation
Order CT angiography of right lower leg
Obtain urgent consultation for emergency fasciotomy
Apply knee immobilizer and elevate the extremity

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While posterior long-leg splinting and orthopedic consultation are appropriate for tibial shaft fractures, the clinical signs of compartment syndrome (tense compartment, neurologic deficit) require another intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

Compartment pressure measurement may be helpful in equivocal cases; however the clinical presentation indicates compartment syndrome with neurologic compromise. Delaying treatment for diagnostic testing could lead to permanent disability.

C) INCORRECT:

CT angiography would be indicated for suspected vascular injury, but the presence of palpable pulses makes this less likely. The clinical signs point to compartment syndrome rather than vascular compromise.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- The combination of a high-energy mechanism, tense swollen anterior compartment, and sensory deficit between the first and second toes (deep peroneal nerve distribution) indicates acute compartment syndrome. Compartment syndrome is a surgical emergency requiring immediate fasciotomy to prevent permanent tissue damage and functional impairment. This condition is a major complication of tibial fractures that can lead to permanent disability if not treated emergently.

E) INCORRECT:

Knee immobilizers are used for tibial plateau fractures, not tibial shaft fractures. Additionally, elevation and conservative measures are contraindicated when compartment syndrome is present, as they may worsen the condition.
